headline: Beef Enchiladas with Flour Tortillas
description: A simple and easy beef enchiladas recipe that comes together quickly. Ground beef and onion are wrapped in tortillas, topped with cheese, and baked.

video.description: These saucy beef enchiladas are simple and quick to make.
video.name: Beef Enchiladas II

name: Beef Enchiladas with Flour Tortillas
recipeIngredient: 1 (1.5 ounce) package dry enchilada sauce mix
1 (2.25 ounce) can sliced black olives, drained

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Cook ground beef and onion in a medium skillet over medium-high heat until beef is evenly browned and onion is tender.
Prepare enchilada sauce according to package directions. Pour 1/4 cup of the sauce into the bottom of a 9x13-inch baking dish.

Place an equal portion of the ground beef mixture and about 1 ounce of Cheddar cheese on each flour tortilla, reserving at least 1/2 cup of cheese. Then tightly roll the tortillas and place seam side down in the baking dish.
Pour remaining sauce over the top of the enchiladas and sprinkle with remaining cheese and olives.
Bake in the preheated oven until the sauce is bubbly and cheese is thoroughly melted, about 20 minutes.

review.reviewBody: I haven’t made these but I want to make a comment regarding the name, these are not enchiladas, these are smothered burritos, which is a Tex-Mex dish. Enchiladas are always made with corn tortillas and burritos utilize flour tortillas. It may sound nit picky, but culturally it makes a big difference.
Easy prep for a dinner on the run. We loved it and leftovers are waiting for tomorrow.

I have used this recipe a few times before, but this time we wanted to spice it up. I also added a half can of refried beans, green pepper, tomatoes and green chilis, taco seasoning! It has become one of my favorite dishes and it is so easy too!
Excellent! Folks, use the beef mixture as topping for nachos…crazy good. I add a can of refried beans in the mix and keep black beans for a cold topping when you take out of oven
Easy to make
I will make this again! Delicious! I added a touch of refried beans. The next time I make this, I will upgrade to a higher quality canned enchilada sauce.
Great recipe!

Loved this recipe !! Taco Bell use to sell this and yes it was called an enchirido waaaaaayyyy back in the day !!!! I do use the taco seasoning which helps !! I also use about 2lbs of beef and save leftovers for other items !!!

I loved this recipe. I looked it up because I forgot what temperature to bake it in. I used shredded beef leftover from a roast. I also serve it with sour cream and lettuce and tomato. If I want the sauce to have extra flavor I add cumin. I like it when someone gives 5 stars and then tells you what they did for personal touches. Thats why I read the comments. So what do ya'll think about a gluten free tortilla lol. Who knew there would be so much controversy over a corn vs flour tortilla.
Made as according to the recipe. Very easy but only change is I would have used taco seasoning for the hamburger mean as well as the enchilada sauce.
Made almost exactly as written, except I forgot to buy tomato sauce for the sauce mix. Used some tomato paste instead, and it worked great.

Liked it. Will make it again. Only thing is that the amounts or proportions were off. Only made 8 of 10 enchiladas. Flavour was great & was easy to prepare. Couldn't find enchilada sauce so used picante sauce instead.
My husband loves these enchiladas!!
Followed the directions. It ended up a bit bland and not very tasty. I won’t be making again.

I don't like corn tortillas for enchiladas because the corn tortillas break up too easy. I also prefer the flour tortillas because they hold together much better when serving them...traditional or not. This recipe is a lot like mine, I just added a can of Ortega green chilies, and they were perfect!

great recipe. one thing I might add is some enchilada sauce to meat just so it's easier to add to tortillas and doesn't fall out. I also added Spanish rice to enhance meat flavor and while this isn't authentic or almost makes it a burrito we don't care....tastes good, easy to make and reasonable cost with plenty of leftovers . Good dish for college students on a budget too....

This recipe is simple, yet delicious. It's one of my fiance's favorites.
Here are some changes I've made:
-Replaced ground beef with ground turkey to make it leaner
-Replaced red enchilada sauce with chile queso for a cheesier bite
-Reduced tortilla count to 4-6, so there's more filling in each enchilada
-Added taco seasoning to the protein (this one is CRUCIAL for getting great flavor)
Loved it
ame out great Thanks
I always use corn for beef and flour for chicken enchiladas..But I add a lot of other things,olives,green chilies and green onions..
It was my 1st time making it so I didn't want anything too complicated. It was really good. I tweaked it a little by using ground turkey instead of beef

Delicious and super easy. I couldn’t find packaged enchilada sauce mix so used about 1/2 of a taco mix package. Otherwise I followed the recipe. However, I love cheese so I did use more cheese than it called for.
I followed the recipe exactly but this is inedible. I have rarely found a recipe on this site that my Dh and I didn't at least finish. We found this dish impossible to eat.

Followed another reviewer's advice and added 1/2 package of taco seasoning to the ground turkey I used and it still wasn't flavorful enough.
Honestly the recipe is perfectly fine - I just felt there could be something more to the mixture inside the enchilada. The flour tortillas also became VERY squishy upon baking. I happen to like that texture, but it was even a bit much for me.

I used canned chicken and it was delicious! I also softened the tortillas in hot oil before I rolled the chicken and cheese in them. 

I do think the nutrition information might be off. Since I used chicken, I compared it to a very similar recipe from this site that used canned chicken. The nutritional values are almost the same, except that this one says one serving is one enchilada while the other said one serving is two enchiladas. It would be nice to know which is correct. 

I'll definitely make this again!

I happen to think that it IS helpful when reviewers talk about the authenticity of a recipe. If you make these and wonder why they don't taste like the enchiladas at your favorite Mexican eatery, it's because they never make enchiladas with flour tortillas. It's a completely different taste! That said, this was an easy, tasty recipe - for smothered burritos. I was really offended by comments such as "not all of us are Mexican" and "keep your comments to yourself". No one who questioned the use of four tortillas was being unkind, but some of the responses to them certainly were.

Very good. I made it mostly following the directions. I did have enchilada sauce mix but used canned sauce, it worked fine. My biggest suggestion would be add maybe a 1/2 cup or more to the meat. And remember there is no such thing as too much cheese. But Cojita or another mMe I can cheese might add something.
Great recipe- I ended up using Taco Mix as I didn't have Enchilada mix. Still loved it!

I loved it, thought it a great recipe for a quick and easy dinner after a long day at work. 
Family loved it, and its very filling.
These would be burritos since they use flour tortillas. For authenticity and MUCH better flavor, sub them for corn tortillas.

Very good. Whether flour or corn, make them as you wish. To me, the flour ones tend to be a bit gummy when they are baked with a sauce. I just use what I have. I've even used a rotisserie chicken from the local supermarket for a quick meal. The nice thing about all of us being creative cooks is that we can tweak recipes as we prefer as long as we have the basic recipe.
Happy cooking, everyone.

I confess, I have not make this specific recipe but if I did, the one thing I would change would be instead of using ground beef, I would use shredded beef. A lot more trouble but gives a richer flavor if seasoned properly. And I LOVE flour tortillas vs corn so I love your idea of using flour. This is definitely great comfort food. You are inspiring me to make these!

Only corn tortillas should be used for enchiladas. They do not over power a dish if you know what you are doing. We are a Mexican family and we are not surprised at recipes made by those north of the border and passed off as Mexican leaving people to believe that the recipe is Mexican. This may be considered Tex-Mex which should never be confused with Mexican. Traditional enchiladas do not need to be reinvented. I am happy that people like this but it is in no way an enchilada. Why don't you try traditional, old school. They are easier, more delicious and don't contain canned sauce or packaged seasoning

I'm just here enjoying all the white people who are angry that real enchiladas are made with corn tortillas. Yup, you can use whatever you want, but they are no longer enchiladas at that point. Enjoy!

I have made this several times and my family loves it. I have to admit that I season the meat and onion with cumin, chili powder, onion and garlic powder, liberally. I fix this along with spanish rice and it is always a hit.
Was real easy to make. Tasted so yummy as my great nieces would say. Sour cream with it is really good.!!!

These would or should more aptly be labeled "Burritos"
Good simple recipe and tastes good

I enjoyed this recipe. I added diced jalepeno for a little kick, but I think I added too much since it was really spicy. My boyfriend loved it! I prepared spanish rice and pinto beans with this dish. I’ll definitely make it again.
So instead of putting cheese in with the meat I put cheese on the tops before putting it in the oven

I really liked this. Loved the homemade sauce ! 

However 4 stars because my husband said it tasted like burritos with a smoky sauce ,( I don’t think he’s ever had anything but canned sauce) he’s a good husband tho - He took the rest to work and while warming it up everyone wanted some !
it was really good but a bit spicier then im use to. Hubby and oldest son loved it. Had to make something else for my 5 year old tho.
I added fresh Jalapeno peppers to the meat mixture and on top. I also added sour cream and green onions to the top.

I have made them hundreds of time! They are amazing and my family loves them. We have them like almost every week.
We add refried beans to them. Yummy
Easy and delicious! Added taco seasoning to meat and used enchilada canned sauce. Will make again

I did change the recipe slightly. I read a few of the other comments and decided to add some cumin and red pepper flakes to the gr beef/onion and fried that down with a small can of green chilies, then added a can of re fried beans and heated till all mixed and hot. Also made 2 cups of white rice (plain). Put a lttle of the canned enchilada sauce on the bottom-assembled the flour tort )sm amount of sauce to coat bottom/beef mix/rice and cheese then rolled them up and put in sauced pan, repeated till all ing were gone, poured all the remaining sauce on top then cheese baked 350 for 30 min....absolutely loved it! Will make again and so easy!
Amazing! My wife loved it
Absolutely will make it again. I'm a pretty novice cook and it was very simple
I made two pans of this for my family when my son was in from Afghanistan. They absolutely loved them!! Needless to say they have become a family favorite.
made my own enchilada sauce and it was a game changer. great simple, easy recipe.
Amazing! This was a phenomenal recipe and I am so grateful to you for sharing it.
the hubby LOVED this. I normally throw in other ingrediants in the enchiladas. I think that is why he loved it, so simple and just good! SO QUICK AND EASY! I will make this again
I listened to everyone's advice and used taco seasoning in the hamburger; otherwise, I followed the recipe. It turned out great!
I used Ten Minute Enchilada Sauce and it was awesome.

Good recipie, for quick & easy!
I am Puerto Rican/Cuban. 
Today I had a lb of hamburger & couldn't think of anything we haven already had in the last week or so...that brought me to this recipie. Good recipie, I used Taco seasoning & a salsa sauce (that's what I had) & added a sm. can of diced chili's made some mexican rice, sm salad & voila...a nice dinner! Enjoy the recipies, adjust to your liking & don't criticize

Great basic recipe! Fun to augment with yummy stuff. I added Rotel and taco seasoning to the meat then sprinkled in some fresh diced jalapeños while rolling the tortillas. It turned out fantastic. (reminder to self: McCormick dry enchilada packet is way better than canned)
i made it and added green chile to the meat as it cooked. thank you for the recipe. it was delicious

I felt it was a little dry. Don't like olives to left those out. Served them on shredded lettuce with salsa and sour cream. Seems it needed more in the filling - rice and cheese? Also had refried beans with cheese. Probably will use a different recipe next time.
Don't think i could ever get tired of this amazing meal!
Ive made this multiple times but your recipe is always the one I use! Know it by heart now just saw it saved in my favorites and wanted you to know we love this meal!

I was agnostic on the tortilla debate, but after making the dish I would definitely recommend corn tortillas if you like a lot of enchilada sauce... The flour ones were a bit gummy. I'm from NM, so I think I'll try white or blue corn tortillas as they have a milder flavor...
Very good. I had no olives but none the less the 10 I made was gone in no time between 3 of us. I used 2lbs of ground beef for 10. I also had to make my own enchilada sauces mix.
This is my favorite!! It's a staple in my family menu. The only thing I changed (as per personal taste) was adding a pack of taco seasoning and lots of garlic. Simple and yet flavorful.
Switched out flour tortillas for corn. Excellent!
I didn't change a thing about the recipe. Service with optional toppings of lettuce, onions, black olives and additional cheese. I also made spanish rice as a side. Simple and delicious.

So very good. Husband couldn't stop raving about it. So easy too. All I did was sprinkle a little chili powder on the beef and onion after browning. Other reviewers mentioned taco seasoning, but husband said that would have been too much, the little chili powder was all I needed.
Gave it a five, picky husband loved it! Will probably make it again
Finally, a meal all three of my kiddos (plus My husband and I) love! This one is a keeper. We didn’t change a thing!!
this is actually what we would call a "smothered burrito" a flour soft burrito with toppping. Still good
Couldn't find the dry enchilada sauce, so I just used canned. Tasty, but not exceptional.

Kinda follow the recipe. I added three hard boiled eggs to the meat mixture, and yes I did use corn tortillas! Layered enchiladas sauce on bottom of pan, placed meat mixture and heap of cheese to tortilla, put a can of tomatoes and green chilies, topped with rest of enchiladas sauce, lots of cheese and black olives. Placed casserole in refrigerator for about 4 hours. Baked 370 for 30 minutes. Topped with cilantro, sour cream and sliced green onions. Delish,

I used green sauce as I was looking to get rid of it. I think I used too much sauce as the tortillas got soggy. However, it tasted good, and my company liked it. I would add taco seasoning next time to give it some spice.
This is an easy and good recipe. I used canned enchiladas sauce. I will not use black olives next time because it doesn't really add anything to the dish.

I preheated my oven to 375 and cooked for 20mins instead of 30. I used corn tortillas instead of flour, cooked up some Mexican rice and add that to my beef mixture along with a cup of cheese, however, not for any reason other than I love Mexican rice and wanted to stuff it into my enchiladas and of corse extra cheese is always awesome.
I made it. It was ok. But I don't know if I'll make it again. I'm just unsure.
Was very solid overall. Also added corn and found that to be a good addition to the recipe

I am making this for the second time this month. I don't know why I never tried making them before. They are so easy to make. My son and I love Mexican food and this is going to be on our menu for years to come.
I love this. It makes a ton but who cares! I've made it twice in the last three months and it's hard not to make again.
Loved the recipe.
Great...I seasoned the meat with taco season, used liquid enchilada sauce and added chopped onions on top. Will definitely make again.
Delicious! No leftovers!
Very good we liked it

The only change I made was to add taco seasoning to the meat and doubled it.. Also offered sour cream as a condiment. Went great with refried beans and rice !!!!! Were no leftovers.M y guest's LOVED IT !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! THANKS for a GREAT post !!!!!!!!!!!!
They were good but I would add some seasoning to the meat. Maybe some taco seasoning

Delish. I just copied a suggestion here and there from the reviews. I especially liked the comment from a review that she added the olives because her family didn't like them. More for us! And flour vs corn tortillas. Folks let's not bicker. I have in my family that don't like the flour so I make half and half. What's the point of a f dish if not everyone likes the same thing.? I prefer flour my family likes the corn.
I only put black olives on one because everyone in my family doesn’t eat them.

It was a long time since I made enchiladas and these brought me back. They are easy to make and had great flavor! I put cheese inside the tortillas too. Also had too double the sauce because we like them saucy. Will make again!

author.name: The best baker in the world

review.reviewBody: I loved this recipe and how they used flour instead of corn tortillas My family loved this

Was a good basic recipe. Nothing special. It needs more spice though. Next time adding a can of chilies to the meat mix, and cayenne or hot sauce . The meat mixture does not fill 10 tortillas, more like 8. Unless you want them super thin. All in all, I think it's definitely a versatile recipe. I can see using with shredded chicken or shredded beef (like left over pot roast or short ribs). And next time using corn tortillas as I normally would.

This was a super easy to make dish. I used flour tortillas because it is what we had in the house. I also added jalepeno's to the meat because we like a little bit of spice. It was not overpowering at all. I used tooth picks to hold the tortillas together when baking them. I also used the canned enchilada sauce & Mexican cheese. It was absolutely delicious with a side of sour cream.
A total hit with my family! Will make it again for sure.
Great recipe, very quick and tasty!

Made this with Corn tortillas and homemade enchilada sauce (https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/219931/quick-enchilada-sauce)

We live in Texas and have a lot of GREAT Mexican restaraunts. The whole family agreed that this recipe blew those restaurants away! THANKS!!!!
Very bland. The beef needs seasoning. But, an easy weeknight meal so worth 3 stars.

This was absolutely delicious, and my picky boyfriend raved on and on about how amazing it tasted. I will make it again!!!!
I followed the recipe with these two tweaks (not really deviating from recipe), which turned out excellently. We like our food a little on the saltier side, so beware of following my tweaks. 
I used one packet of El Paso taco seasoning when browning the beef. This made it extra tasty, but again, we like our food on the more flavorful side. 
The tortillas I bought from Whole Foods horribly broke apart as I was following directions and trying to roll the enchiladas. I then decided to deconstruct it and layered enchilada sauce, the tortillas next on the bottom , then meat mixture, then tortilla, then sauce, then cheese, and finally a can of black olives. No rolling!!! 
If you’re not great at rolling or don’t want to roll, just layer like a casserole or lasagna type dish. It works wonders.
Made some changes. Also changed type of cheese
Yummy!

Disclosure: I am also a full blown Mexican. But also disclosure: I’m open minded and not condescending. Ok sometimes I am. Anyway, yes authentic enchiladas are made with corn tortillas but 1. Why are you on here if you already know how you want your enchiladas 2. If you know how to make authentic enchiladas you’ll know that it’s a little more time consuming and you have more steps to take 3. This is allrecipes (not your grandmas cookbook from Mexico). Just because it’s not the “real” thing doesn’t mean it’s bad. I did like them btw. Thanks OP for sharing and sorry some people are so rude. As a Mexican, you other Hispanics should also know that part of the culture of our cooking is sharing recipes and adapting them to suit your families tastes.
My family really enjoyed it. I liked that it was easy and quick. Will be making it again!!
I liked the simplicity of the dish. however I did not use the enchilada sauce packet, instead I used the sauce in the can and Jack cheese instead of cheddar. very delicious.
